text.p: The surface integral of a vector field over an area is called 'flux'. This surface integral is important because it provides a useful connection between the distribution of field intensity over a closed surface and the charge inside that surface. The word ‘flux' was first used in studies of velocity fields where there was an actual flow of matter across a surface. In electrostatics nothing is flowing, but electric flux is still the name used for this surface integral. This integral is often written as [mathjaxinline]\int \! \! \! \int _{\rm S} \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{A}[/mathjaxinline]; it is also written as [mathjaxinline]\int _{\rm S} \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{A}.[/mathjaxinline] A circle on the integral sign, [mathjaxinline]\oint _{\rm S} \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{A}[/mathjaxinline], means that the surface integration is over a closed surface.
